children.value: is currenly highly experimental and may change significantly in minor releases and ev en patch releases. Pin down your loaders.gl version if you wish to use it.
class creates a base64 encoded GIF image from either:
only works in the browser, and many features are experimental.
Build a GIF from image URLs (Experimental)
Build a GIF from image URLs, with frame-specific Text (Experimental)
Build a GIF from the webcam (Experimental)
Experimentally, tha following types can currently be added (may be removed in upcoming release)
If this option is used, then a GIF will be created using these images e.g. ,.'
a GIF will be created using the first supplied video that is supported by the current browser's video codecs. E.g. 'example.mp4', 'example.ogv'.
Also note that a mix of types is not supported. All added elements must be of the same type (images, image URLs, video URLs).
The build method will actually build the GIF. It returns a base 64 encoded GIF.
this builder instance is not intended to be used further. Create new
Desired width of the generated GIF image
Desired height of the generated GIF image
CORS attribute for requesting image or video URLs. 'Anonymous'
pixels to skip when creating the palette. Default is 10. Less is better, but slower.
The amount of time (in seconds) to wait between each frame capture

By adjusting the sample interval, you can either produce extremely high-quality images slowly, or produce good images in reasonable times. With a sampleInterval of 1, the entire image is used in the learning phase, while with an interval of 10, a pseudo-random subset of 1/10 of the pixels are used in the learning phase. A sampling factor of 10 gives a substantial speed-up, with a small quality penalty.
These options are forwarded directly to the underlying
module. They are not officially supported by loaders.gl, but can still be useful. In case things are unclear it is recommended to search the documentation and issues in that module.
when the current image is completed
`'', // CSS filter that will be applied to the image (eg. blur(5px))
If an image is given here, it will be stamped on top of the GIF frames
The X (horizontal) Coordinate of the watermark image
The Y (vertical) Coordinate of the watermark image
'', // The text that covers the animated GIF | |

true | If frame-specific text is supplied with the image array, you can force the |frame-specific text to not be displayed by making this option 'false'.
|
'normal' | The font weight of the text that covers the animated GIF | |

'16px' | The font size of the text that covers the animated GIF |
|
'10px' | The minimum font size of the text that covers the animated GIF (Note
This |option is only applied if the text being applied is cut off) |

false | Whether or not the animated GIF text will be resized to fit within the GIF |container
|
'sans-serif' | The font family of the text that covers the animated GIF | |

'#ffffff' | The font color of the text that covers the animated GIF |
|
'center' | The horizontal text alignment of the text that covers the animated GIF | |

'bottom' | The vertical text alignment of the text that covers the animated GIF |
|
null | The X (horizontal) Coordinate of the text that covers the animated GIF (only |use this if the default textAlign and textBaseline options don't work for you) |
null | The Y (vertical) Coordinate of the text that covers the animated GIF (only |use this if the default textAlign and textBaseline options don't work for you)
Make sure these image resources are CORS enabled to prevent any cross-origin JavaScript errors
You may also pass a NodeList of existing image elements on the page
